description: From Middle English smutten (“to defile, debase”), related to German Schmutz (“filth, dirt, smut”) and schmutzen (“to make dirty, stain”).  Doublet of schmutz.
Compare also Old English smitta (“smear; blot; mark; stain; pollution”), Old English besmītan (“to besmut; defile; dirty; pollute; contaminate”).

entries.meaning: (countable) A flake of ash or soot.
(uncountable) Sexually vulgar material; something that is sexual in a dirty way; pornographic material.

examples: He does not stand upon decency  […]  but will talk smut, though a priest and his mother be in the room.

entries.meaning: Any of a range of fungi, mostly Ustilaginomycetes, that cause plant disease in grasses, including cereal crops; the disease so caused.
(mining) Bad, soft coal containing earthy matter, found in the immediate locality of faults.

verbs.description: smut (third-person singular simple present smuts, present participle smutting, simple past and past participle smutted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To stain (or be stained) with soot or other dirt.
(transitive) To taint (grain, etc.) with the smut fungus.
(intransitive) To become tainted by the smut fungus.
examples: It smutted to a far greater degree than the year before, say three fourths, or more. I obtained but little more than the seed sown, and that was handsome wheat. This failure I imputed to the same supposed cause which operated the last year.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To clear of the smut fungus.
examples: to smut grain for the mill
